Homeless struggle to find health care

  • By Kelcie Landon
Jan. 31 11:12 pm
  • 78072 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2011%2F01%2F31%2Fhomeless-struggle-to-find-health-care%2F7807%2FHomeless+struggle+to+find+health+care2011-02-01+04%3A12%3A29Kelcie+Landonhttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D7807
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Sources

  • Sherry Hay, employee, Carolina Health Net
  • DeAnn Jarman, homeless resident
  • Rick Lambert, homeless resident
  • Jamie Rohe, coordinator, Project Homeless Connect
  • Wayne Sherman, personal health services provider, Orange County Health Department
  • Tim Smith, employee, Carolina Health Net
  • Brian Toomey, CEO, Piedmont Health Services
  • Laurie Tucker, housing director, Inter-Faith Council

CHAPEL HILL
It’s late. The darkness and silence are severed by the wail of an ambulance as it races down Franklin Street, lights flashing. Drivers pull over to let it pass as the dispatch officer comes over the radio and describes a patient who claims to have intense chest pain.

When emergency medical technicians arrive on the scene, however, they find a man who called simply for a ride to the hospital, looking for health care that could be just as well received at any primary care physician’s office.

This man does not have a steady income or a home, let alone health insurance or a doctor that he visits on a regular basis.

Despite various health care services offered through the Orange County Health Department and Inter-Faith Council homeless shelters, many homeless individuals in Orange County still resort to using the emergency departments at UNC Hospitals as their primary care provider.

Getting into the health care system

The Inter-Faith Council For Social Service provides basic health care services through the Robert Nixon Free Clinic for the Homeless.

“It is more of a triage service,” said Laurie Tucker, housing director for the council. “We are not really your traditional clinic.”

Tucker said that the IFC provides services such as blood pressure and diabetes screening and will treat patients on location if they can. Otherwise, they will be referred out to other doctors or the hospital.

One of the stipulations for receiving care at this clinic is that a person must stay at the shelter. The council will also provide vouchers for individuals who stay in their shelters to cover the cost of seeing a regular doctor at Piedmont Health Services.

But the requirement of living at the shelter excludes some of the homeless population from receiving these benefits.

Rick Lambert spends his nights in a camp in the the woods in the northern part of the county and his days on Franklin Street. He was asked to leave shelter after accusations of trespassing.

Lambert has experienced abnormal bone growth and degenerative disks in his spine since he was hit by a car as a child. He also lost access to his antipsychotic medication when he left the shelter.

“I go to the hospital when I get sick,” Lambert said. “I have applied for Medicaid four different times, but I always get denied because I don’t have children of my own.”

Lambert was recently suffering with a hernia but said the hospital wouldn’t treat him because it wasn’t an emergency.

“When this hernia ruptures and I end up in the hospital, they’re going to be the ones who are hurt, because they are going to have to pay a lot because I was unable to receive adequate care,” Lambert said.

“It’s like they pick and choose who they want to help.”

Finding primary care

Carolina Health Net, founded in the spring of 2008, is one of the organizations working to fill these holes in access to care for the homeless population.

Carolina Health Net is a partnership between UNC Health Care, Piedmont Health Services and UNC-Chapel Hill’s School of Medicine. Their mission is to direct individuals away from using emergency services as primary care and help them find doctors they can visit regularly.

“We have a navigator there five days a week, and if someone happens to come in while she was there, she would identify them and meet with them and talk with them about their options,” said Sherry Hay, project director for Carolina Health Net.

Hay said the navigator would establish clients with a doctor that they know and trust and connect them with a pharmacy.

About 150 uninsured individuals come to the emergency department every month with non-emergency situations and are referred to primary care physicians through Carolina Health Net, Hay said.

Carolina Health Net has a contract with Piedmont Health Services, which means that when the navigator refers patients to a doctor, they usually end up at one of Piedmont’s six clinics.

Brian Toomey, CEO of Piedmont Health Services, said the program is about the “four rights”: getting the right care, at the right place, at the right time and at the right cost.

“[Carolina Health Net] saves money because when someone comes to the emergency room without medical insurance and receives treatment, that is uncompensated cost,” Toomey said.

“Fifteen to 20 percent of everyone’s insurance premium goes to covering these uncompensated costs. It also reduces opportunity cost, which is the person who was turned away at the ER because all the beds were full.”

But some people find it difficult to receive health care through this system.

DeAnn Jarman, who also chooses not to live in the shelter, is paralyzed on her right side and has no source of income. Jarman said she is disinclined to go to Piedmont Health Services to receive health care because she cannot afford to pay the premium.

Piedmont Health operates on a sliding fee scale. The lowest fee that a person will have to pay is $25, which applies to people who are within 200 percent of the poverty line.

“We don’t turn away anyone. We will help people who can’t pay work out a payment plan,” Toomey said.

But Jarman and many others aren’t aware of this policy. All they know is that the $25 premium is enough to put health care a few notches lower on their list of priorities.

“We have no income, but we have to pay $25 to go to Piedmont Health. That means that if we want to go to the doctor, we have to panhandle $25,” Jarman said.

Piedmont Health is not the only place to receive primary health care in the area. The Orange County Health Department offers access to primary care physicians, also on a sliding fee scale, with a minimum payment of $15.

The health department, however, has stricter standards concerning who can receive primary health care services from them.

Wayne Sherman, personal health services director for the health department, said that to be connected to primary care services, a person has to be a resident of Orange County and eligible to receive certain services like prenatal care and family planning services.

All the services required for eligibility are directed toward women and children.

“We are not an urgent care center, and we do not serve just anyone in the community,” Sherman said. “Let’s say you are a homeless man who is 50 years old. You do not fit the profile of people we can serve.”

Barriers within the health care system

The people who work most closely with the homeless population and attempt to connect them with health care are constantly working to overcome barriers within the system.

“Once they may have gotten into a service and have been seen, they have difficulty paying the minimum fee and receiving follow-up care,” Sherman said. He also said transportation to and from health care providers was often an issue.

Tim Smith, program associate for Carolina Health Net, identified transiency as a major problem in establishing stable health care.

“The homeless are hard to get in touch with,” Smith said. “They change locations rapidly. They might seem interested in the emergency room, but they are hard to follow up with. And sometimes they are just at a point in their lives where they just are not ready to receive constant health care.”

Chronic diseases are particularly difficult. For example, diabetics have to keep their insulin refrigerated, which is a major obstacle for the homeless. Another challenge is finding a way to receive medication regularly.

Events like Project Homeless Connect that work in conjunction with Carolina Health Net have made significant strides in overcoming these obstacles and are well-received throughout the homeless population.

Project Homeless Connect works to provide many overlooked services to these people at one location in one day.

Through the project they can receive legal services, blood pressure and vision screening, testing for sexually transmitted infections, and many other amenities. People are then connected with physicians and receive valuable advice on how to manage their own health.

But as popular and extensive as Project Homeless Connect is, it only occurs one day out of the year. During the other 364 days, the obstacles still remain. Hundreds of people still find it difficult to access reliable health care.

Ultimately, Toomey said, it’s a cycle with many components, all of which must be addressed for any significant advances to happen.

“Food and shelter come first,” Toomey said. “That is what these people want and need most, as well as just for somebody to give a damn about them.”

“If those basic needs can be met, then people will pay more attention to things like chronic illnesses and health care,” he said.

This article was reported as part of the J253 Reporting and News Writing course at UNC’s School of Journalism and Mass Communication.
